author: sky.cactus
content: My personal opinion is that we should have tests for behavior below 7, because the inability to drop below 7 is merely a side effect and not an expected behavior.  In the future, there may be some change that allows it to drop below 7 and we wouldn't want that to cause a consensus failure.

author: sky.cactus
content: <:notsureif:710333259086823464> divide what by 500M?

author: .vbuterin
content: Divide the expected MEV of the block by 500 million

author: timbeiko
content: Using this, with an average MEV of .2 ETH/block (roughly what it was in the flasbots graph I showed) you get 4 gwei for MEV uncle risk + 1 gwei for BR uncle risk = 5 gwei

author: timbeiko
content: I'm curious why Vitalik's algorithm ~= 2x what BarnabÃ©'s notebook suggests ðŸ¤”

author: sky.cactus
content:
2 ETH => 4 nanoeth per gas
0.2 ETH => 0.4 nanoeth per gas

author: barnabemonnot
content: thanks for sharing! I guess I missed it when it came out...

author: jetjadeja
content: How would one calculate the expected MEV for an upcoming block?

author: sky.cactus
content: You would have to do it as part of block construction.  As you build the block, you can keep a running total of coinbase increases and raise the minimum priority fee as you go.

author: jetjadeja
content: Ah that makes a lot of sense.

author: jetjadeja
content: Any reason why you should divide it by 500 million, specifically?

author: swcbbs3087
content: What is minimum priority fee?

author: sky.cactus
content: The lowest priority fee per gas a miner is willing to accept for including a transaction.

author: spalladino
content: qq: how would nodes react if they receive a tx with maxFee lower than the current block's baseFee? would they reject the tx immediately (as it happens today if an account tries to send a tx without enough balance to pay for its cost), or would they accept it into their mempool to process it when the baseFee lowers?

author: ryan5th_l6840
content: <@385149230899003392> i think the 2nd part of this pic is what youâ€™re asking?

author: timbeiko
content: <@!486501030046203915> I was going over the uncle risk stuff for the tip today to make sure I understood it and I think I found a more recent proxy for `p` in your note we can use.

author: timbeiko
content: Vitalik mentioned he had looked at https://etherchain.org/correlations and compared gas used to uncle rate to see how increasing the gas in a block leads to increased uncle rates

author: timbeiko
content: Using the recent block increase, we get this

author: timbeiko
content:
If we eyeball it, the gas limit goes from ~12.25m to ~14.75m, so +2.5m. In that, it seems like the uncle rates go from clustering around .045 to .049 (being somewhat generous), so a ~0.004 increase in uncle rate for a 2.5m increase. This means a 10m gas would add ~1.6% uncle risk, not 2.5% as your note assumes. 

Would it be possible to re-chart your last graph using 2% to see how it changes?

author: spalladino
content: Sorry, I wasn't clear about what fee I was referring to. What I meant is: if I send a transaction with feeCap = 500gwei (regardless of the priority fee), and the baseFee in the current block is 600 gwei, would the tx be immediately rejected by the receiving node, or would it keep it in its mempool?

author: brad.decker
content: Question regarding implementation. At MetaMask we have a cancel/speed up transaction feature -- If anyone has any information about the impact of EIP-1559 on submitting new transactions with the same nonce. I believe that currently there's like a 10% minimum bump in gas price for it to be considered. As I understand it getting a transaction included ahead of another with the same nonce has multiple sliders now, is there any current thoughts on this? Also apologies if this isn't the right place I'll relocate the message if a better channel exists.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@415548822983278593> or <@543900561460822016> probably know the latest answer to that.
